text: thumb|right|upright=2|Unit cell of CaF2, known as fluorite structure, from two equivalent perspectives. In the antifluorite structure, the blue positions are taken by the anion, the red positions by the cation. In crystallography, an anti-structure is obtained from a salt structure by exchanging anion and cation positions. For instance, calcium fluoride, CaF2, crystallizes in a cubic motif called the fluorite structure. The same crystal structure is found in numerous ionic compounds with formula AB2, such as ceria (CeO2), zirconia (cubic ZrO2), uranium dioxide (UO2). In the corresponding anti-structure, called the antifluorite structure, anions and cations are swapped, such as beryllium carbide (Be2C) or lithium oxide (Li2O), potassium sulfate (K2SO4).
